page.title: 02Landscapes and Buildings
page.content: This is an area of small family farms in flat countryside which avoids bleakness through its many hedges & trees, a green backcloth for the old farmhouses and farmbuildings. There are many hamlets and groups of houses but the chief residential area is The Street at Smarden, dominated by the stone church tower to the west. This harmonious group of houses, built over 4 centuries, displays several types of local material: brick, tile-hanging, plaster & beam and most prominently, weatherboard. Kentish ragstone was used for the church, school, Old Rectory and one pair of cottages near the church. The local authority has established a conservation area around the church, where building is strictly controlled and the appearance of the old houses maintained. Only 2 examples of thatched houses remain.
